author: jpsnover
body:
We alias MAN to be get-help and that is fine BUT it has to work properly.  People need to be able to find their man pages.  

Our behavior is to find the help associated with a name and if we can't, we'll do a search.  I think we need to look for the native help between those two steps.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
Agreement within the PowerShell sync to remove this alias and create an actual 'man powershell' page which explains how to use Get-Help. 

Dovetails into the larger Linux /bin/\* alias problem. We'll be enumerating all of these aliases soon.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
The solution (for now) is to just remove the `man` alias, such that `help` opens PowerShell's help and `man` opens the Linux manual. This is exactly how Bash works as well.

While we can certainly fix the `Get-Help` cmdlet to fall-through and search the man pages, I consider this future work.

Irrespective of the aliasing problem, the open question is whether we go into Linux man to find help when our help system fails to find a topic.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: FYI, `man` is no longer a problem here since we decided to remove the *nix-y aliases on Linux/macOS. Still, we should do something about the Get-Help scenario.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Enhancing the `Get-Help` cmdlet to fall-through to *nix man pages would be a great Hacktoberfest pull request!

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
The problem now is that you've trained Windows PowerShell users to use `man` for viewing help. When they get to PS Core on Linux, they'll run into this:
```
PS /home/hillr> man about_requires
No manual entry for about_requires
```
:-(

comments.author: davidBar-On
comments.body: A note to whoever will try to fix this issue - see PR #15343 with a proposed fix for the issue.

title: Our MAN (and get-help) should fall through to /usr/bin/man on failure to find something
